RCSB MBT Libs

The Molecular Biology Toolkit (MBT) is a Java-based protein visualization and analysis toolkit.

Packages
org.rcsb.mbt.controllers.app The App is the initiating and contact point for the application.
org.rcsb.mbt.controllers.doc This package consists fundamentally of the DocController class.
org.rcsb.mbt.controllers.scene The scene is the graphics representation of the model.
org.rcsb.mbt.controllers.update When the model or other aspects of the scene or viewer changes, update notifications need to be forwarded to the concerned parties.

org.rcsb.mbt.model This is the model description package.
org.rcsb.mbt.model.attributes Describes attributes that can be associated with 'StructureComponent' objects.
org.rcsb.mbt.model.cppConversion  
org.rcsb.mbt.model.filters This package provides classes which enable filtering or subsetting of a structure's constituent components.
org.rcsb.mbt.model.geometry A full suite of geometrical manipulation utilities - matrices, vectors, etc.
org.rcsb.mbt.model.util This package provides classes which implement extra functionality on top of the core MBT classes (that is, capabilities that are not absolutely required by, or would otherwise overcomplicate, the core classes).
org.rcsb.mbt.structLoader File loaders are contained in this package.
org.rcsb.mbt.ui.dialogs Various generic dialogs that are useful to choose colors, choose files, report progress, etc.
org.rcsb.mbt.ui.mainframe Contains the base class for the main or 'document frame', and components common to it.
org.rcsb.mbt.ui.views Contains low-level view objects.
org.rcsb.mbt.ui.views.StructureViewerImpl This collection of classes creates the geometry for the various secondary structures.
org.rcsb.mbt.ui.views.StructureViewerImpl.vec Basic vector descriptors.

 

The Molecular Biology Toolkit (MBT) is a Java-based protein visualization and analysis toolkit. The toolkit provides classes for efficiently loading, managing and manipulating large amounts of protein structure and sequence data.

Re-Architecting Effort

The MBT was originally written in JDK 1.0, before many well-accepted software practices had been more formally defined, and before more efficient and type-safe coding constructs were available in Java.

In this revision, we have restructured key aspects of the architecture to follow more clearly lines of architectural delineation, and to break out coding modules more cleanly. This has meant a re-structuring of the namespace — almost all of the packages have been replaced/renamed to more accurately reflect their functional grouping.

We have also endeavored to upgrade code usage to JDK 1.5 constructs in key areas. Much remains to be done, but overall, the MBT is now poised to provide support in a growing number of applications.

For further information on the architecture, go to the Architecture Overview page.

Usage Overview

The MBT software components were designed with efficiency and ease-of-use in mind. In addition to the necessary data container objects, file parsers, and basic data manipulation code, we wanted to supply the developer with a set of high-level components which could be "plugged" together to produce advanced programs with a minimal amount of user code.

MBT Data Model

The MBT data model is really quite simple. There is one parent data class (the StructureComponent class) from which all other data objects are derived (this class will be explained later). The top-level container for a data-set is the Structure class. A Structure provides access to a set of tables of all sub-components (eg: Atom, Residue, etc). Each record is accessed with "array-like" methods (eg: getStructureComponentCount and getStructureComponent).
